text:
- Making a splash in
the arena of sports
takes determination and passion.

For one local surfer in the
South African coastal town

of Victoria Bay, riding the
wave has led her to the top
of the surfing world.

Surfing is one of the only
times you stop thinking,

and everything's
just reactional.

It's almost like this
instinctive feeling just
comes out.

You're almost like-- you
lose complete control,

and you become completely
dependent on what

the environment is doing
at the exact second.

And then you adapt to
every change that happens.
BIANCA BUITENDAG: Hey, guys.
I'm Bianca Buitendag.

I'm a professional surfer from
Victoria Bay in South Africa.
And this is my Africa.

- She Is the only South African
female professional surfer
on the world tour.

And her skill has propelled
her to consistently rank within
the top 15 surfers on the tour.

BIANCA BUITENDAG: At the
moment, we're in Victoria
Bay, my humble abode.

I live just a
kilometer up the hill.

I grabbed a cup of tea,
and I'm about to head
out for my morning surf.

When I was 12, my
parents packed up,
and we moved from Cape Town.
We got out of the city.

We got out of the craze, got out
of the stress and everything.

And we stayed in this house
just here for year with no TV,
nothing.

So we would spend more time
in the water than outside.

Depending on the tide, you
choose either the slipway
or the backdoor.

I like the fact that
it's one of the most
consistent waves in the world.

I got into surfing
at a very young age.

My dad was a surfer
throughout his life,

and it was just natural
that he would pass that on.

I regard it as
something I inherited.

And it's one of my
biggest loves today.

So I got in surfing, I think,
at the age of six or seven.

- Her earliest
childhood memories are
of surf trips with the family.

BIANCA BUITENDAG: I remember
it being early, early morning

and my dad putting
us on his shoulders,

putting us in the car,
and strapping us up.

And my mom in the
passenger seat, and they

have the map out, and
they were trying to decide
which direction to go.

And then we would
set off, and the sun

would rise above the mountains
here on the Garden Route.

And I remember the whole
adventure part of surfing.

It was it was always just
an excuse to adventure,

whether we were going an hour
away, going to the local beach,
or setting off for a trip.

Boards on the roof, dogs in the
back, brothers side by side.

- At the age of 10, Bianca
started competing locally.

BIANCA BUITENDAG: I
started as a young girl

from South Africa
without much expectation

but with a lot of
ambition and passion.

And I think that drove me to
really give it a good shot.

- Seven years later,
her talent became
her passport to the world.

It led her to competitions
in far-flung destinations

across the globe, from France
to Ecuador to Australia.

BIANCA BUITENDAG: I
started at the bottom
of the qualifying series.

And last year I ended in
the top five of the world.
- Short board or long board?
BIANCA BUITENDAG: Short board.

- Channel Islands
JS, or Firewire?

BIANCA BUITENDAG:
Channel Islands by miles.
- Goofy or natural?

BIANCA BUITENDAG:
Goofy, for sure.

- What does it take to
be a world-class surfer?

BIANCA BUITENDAG:
Passion, resilience.
- Top surf destination?
BIANCA BUITENDAG: Fiji.

- Fiji is just one of 10
countries she's traveled

to in her pursuit of
taking the top spot
on the champion circuit.

BIANCA BUITENDAG:
During the year,

I would spend about 9 or 10
months on the road, of which
we moved every three weeks.

So you're constantly
on the move.
You're living out of a suitcase.

Your board bag is the most
consistent part of your life.

- While the ride is thrilling,
the lifestyle can be testing.

Being on tour means she
spends 10 months of the year
chasing the next wave.

BIANCA BUITENDAG: The
biggest challenge,

especially within the last
six years since I started

traveling, was, I
think, being alone,

whether it's being alone
overseas when you're traveling

in different situations at
airports, being left behind,
coming too early--

all sorts of a tricky
situations you find yourself

in-- in an unfamiliar
environment,

but also being alone
once you come back,

where you've grown
in one direction,

and other people have
grown in a different.
[speaking afrikaans]
[laughter]

- But during her two
months of down time a year,

she comes home to
find her balance.

Home is where she participates
in the uniquely South

African traditions, like
making potjie, a local stew,
on the beach with her brothers.

BIANCA BUITENDAG: What
do I do to unwind?

My favorite thing is
just to keep quiet.

In an industry and in a
world where there's so much

information and so much
criteria and opinion,

everything always swirling
around, just to come home--

even coming home is already
an unwinding or detaching.

And to be here on the Garden
Route is the extreme of that.

So just to go somewhere where
you don't see any person,

whether you're
looking right or left,

and just, yeah, keep quiet and
just observe and be thankful.

- And while she makes her
living amongst the waves,
Africa is always calling.

BIANCA BUITENDAG: My Africa
is-- in Afrikaans we say,
[afrikaans].

It's the diamond in my heart,
a place of real beauty.

If someone mentions the
word Africa, I just blossom.

It's so intertwined
in my being that I

feel like my whole life's
ambition would be to benefit
this place in some way--

first through showing
people that it's possible,

I think, to reach a dream
or to reach a goal, where

a lot of the mentality
here is a place where

it says your circumstances
won't allow it.
The opportunities aren't there.

Just to make people believe
that that's all a lie
and you really can.

If I had to dedicate
my career to anything,
it'll be God's grace.

I was a little blond kid
from Big Bay with a big heart

and a big passion
and a big ambition.

But it was definitely Him that
carried me all the way across.
- Her personal goal?

To put Africa on the
global surfing map.

BIANCA BUITENDAG: The dream
in surfing specifically

is to reach potential
in the sense

that I would think to
end in the top five

or top three within
the next three years.
